Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of NSAIDs as Adjunctive Analgesia in Postoperative Critical Care

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either NSAIDs as adjunctive therapy to opioids or opioids alone.

Participants.evidence: 1,621 adult patients admitted to the ICU for postoperative management after elective procedures.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either NSAIDs as adjunctive therapy to opioids or opioids alone.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of NSAIDs as adjunctive analgesia to opioids in postoperative critical care patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was opioid utilization, measured as 24-hour oral morphine equivalent (OME) consumption.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Data were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: NSAID adjunctive therapy reduced 24-hour OME consumption by 21.4 mg (95% CI, 11.8 to 31.0 mg reduction; p < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events, including gastrointestinal bleeding and acute kidney injury, were infrequent and not significantly different between groups.
